item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Alright, so I’ve gotten it half way working. Problem is, when there is white space, the reader just closes.

	public static int loadGame(Client player, String playerName,
			String playerPass) {
		System.out.println(playerName + " " + playerPass);
		try (BufferedReader reader = Files.newBufferedReader(
				Paths.get("./Data/characters/" + playerName + ".txt"), charset)) {
			String line = reader.readLine().trim();
			String[] args = null;
			while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null
					&& (args = line.split(" ")) != null) {
				if (line.startsWith("Password:")) {
					if (playerPass.equalsIgnoreCase(args[1])) {
						playerPass = args[1];
					} else {
						return 3;
					}
				} else if (line.startsWith("Rights:")) {
					player.playerRights = Integer.parseInt(args[1]);
				} else if (line.startsWith("PlayerX:")) {
					player.teleportToX = Integer.parseInt(args[1]);
				} else if (line.startsWith("PlayerY:")) {
					player.teleportToX = Integer.parseInt(args[1]);
				} else if (line.startsWith("Height:")) {
					player.heightLevel = Integer.parseInt(args[1]);
				} else if (line.startsWith("Inventory Item:")) {
					player.playerItems[Integer.parseInt(args[1])] = Integer
							.parseInt(args[2]);
					player.playerItemsN[Integer.parseInt(args[1])] = Integer
							.parseInt(args[3]);
				} else if (line.startsWith("Bank Item:")) {
					player.bankItems[Integer.parseInt(args[1])] = Integer
							.parseInt(args[2]);
					player.bankItemsN[Integer.parseInt(args[1])] = Integer
							.parseInt(args[3]);
				} else if (line.startsWith("Skill Level")) {
					player.playerLevel[Integer.parseInt(args[1])] = Integer
							.parseInt(args[2]);
					player.playerXP[Integer.parseInt(args[1])] = Integer
							.parseInt(args[3]);
				} else if (line.equals("[EOF]")) {
					try {
						reader.close();
					} catch (IOException e) {
						e.printStackTrace();
					}
				}
				return 1;
			}
		} catch (NoSuchFileException f) {
			new File("./Data/characters/" + playerName + ".txt");
			return 0;
		} catch (IOException e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
			return 3;
		}
		return 13;
	}

Any idea on how to keep it alive all the way through, instead of putting a continue statement at the end of every if?
